The Use of Maxlength in the RPKI The Use of Maxlength in the RPKI
draft-yossigi-rpkimaxlen-01 draft-yossigi-rpkimaxlen-02
Abstract Abstract
This document recommends that operators avoid using the maxLength This document recommends that operators avoid using the maxLength
attribute when issuing Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs) in the attribute when issuing Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs) in the
Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI). These recommendations Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI). These recommendations
complement those in [RFC7115]. complement those in [RFC7115].

1. Introduction 1. Introduction
The RPKI [RFC6480] uses Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs) to create The RPKI [RFC6480] uses Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs) to create
a trusted mapping from an IP prefix to a set of autonomous systems a cryptographically verifiable mapping from an IP prefix to a set of
(ASes) that are authorized to originate this prefix. Each ROA autonomous systems (ASes) that are authorized to originate this
contains a set of IP prefixes, and an AS number of an AS authorized prefix. Each ROA contains a set of IP prefixes, and an AS number of
originate all the IP prefixes in the set [RFC6482]. Each ROA is an AS authorized originate all the IP prefixes in the set [RFC6482].
cryptographically signed by the party that is authorized to allocate The ROA is cryptographically signed by the party that holds a
the set of IP prefixes. certificate for the set of IP prefixes.
The RPKI also supports a maxLength attribute. According to The ROA format also supports a maxLength attribute. According to
[RFC6482], "When present, the maxLength specifies the maximum length [RFC6482], "When present, the maxLength specifies the maximum length
of the IP address prefix that the AS is authorized to advertise." of the IP address prefix that the AS is authorized to advertise."
Thus, rather than requiring the ROA to explictly list each prefix the Thus, rather than requiring the ROA to list each prefix the AS is
AS is authorized to originate, the maxLength attribute provides a authorized to originate, the maxLength attribute provides a shorthand
shorthand that authorizes an AS to originate a set of IP prefixes. that authorizes an AS to originate a set of IP prefixes.
However, measurements of current RPKI deployments have found that use However, measurements of current RPKI deployments have found that use
of the maxLength in ROAs tends to lead to security problems. of the maxLength in ROAs tends to lead to security problems.
Specifically, as of June 2017, 84% of the prefixes specified in ROAs Specifically, as of June 2017, 84% of the prefixes specified in ROAs
that use the maxLength attribute, are vulnerable to a forged-origin that use the maxLength attribute, are vulnerable to a forged-origin
subprefix hijack. The forged-origin subprefix hijack can be launched subprefix hijack [insert citation]. The forged-origin subprefix
against any IP prefix that is authorized in ROA but is not originated hijack, as described below, can be launched against any IP prefix
in BGP. The impact of such an attack is the same as standard that is authorized in ROA but is not originated in BGP. The impact
subprefix hijack on an IP prefix that is unprotected by a ROA in the of such an attack is the same as that of a subprefix hijack in the
RPKI. absence of ROA-based protection.
For this reason, this document recommends that, whenever possible, For this reason, this document recommends that, whenever possible,
operators SHOULD use "minimal ROAs" that include only those IP operators SHOULD use "minimal ROAs" that include only those IP
prefixes that are actually originated in BGP, and no other prefixes. prefixes that are actually originated in BGP, and no other prefixes.
Operators SHOULD also avoid using the maxLength attribute in their Operators SHOULD also avoid using the maxLength attribute in their
ROAS whenever possible. One ideal place to implement these ROAS whenever possible. One ideal place to implement these
recommendations is in the user interfaces for configuring ROAs. recommendations is in the user interfaces for configuring ROAs: thus
this document further recommends that designers and/or providers of
such user interfaces SHOULD provide warnings to draw the user's
attention to the risks of using the maxLength attribute.
The recommendations in this document clarify and extend the following The recommendations in this document clarify and extend the following
recommendation from [RFC7115]: recommendation from [RFC7115]:
One advantage of minimal ROA length is that the forged origin One advantage of minimal ROA length is that the forged origin
attack does not work for sub-prefixes that are not covered by attack does not work for sub-prefixes that are not covered by
overly long max length. For example, if, instead of overly long max length. For example, if, instead of
10.0.0.0/16-24, one issues 10.0.0.0/16 and 10.0.42.0/24, a forged 10.0.0.0/16-24, one issues 10.0.0.0/16 and 10.0.42.0/24, a forged
origin attack cannot succeed against 10.0.666.0/24. They must origin attack cannot succeed against 10.0.666.0/24. They must
attack the whole /16, which is more likely to be noticed because attack the whole /16, which is more likely to be noticed because

3. Forged Origin Subprefix Hijack 3. Forged Origin Subprefix Hijack
The forged-origin subprefix hijack is relevant to a scenario in which The forged-origin subprefix hijack is relevant to a scenario in which
(1) the RPKI [RFC6480] is deployed, and (2) routers use RPKI origin (1) the RPKI [RFC6480] is deployed, and (2) routers use RPKI origin
validation to drop invalid routes [RFC6811], but (3) BGPSEC validation to drop invalid routes [RFC6811], but (3) BGPSEC [RFC8205]
[I-D.ietf-sidr-bgpsec-protocol] is not deployed. (or any similar method to validate the truthfulness of the BGP
AS_PATH attribute) is not deployed.
We describe the forged-origin subprefix hijack [RFC7115] [GCHSS] We describe the forged-origin subprefix hijack [RFC7115] [GCHSS]
using a running example. using a running example.
Consider the IP prefix 168.122.0.0/16 which is allocated to an Consider the IP prefix 168.122.0.0/16 which is allocated to an
organization that also operates AS 111. In BGP, AS 111 originates organization that also operates AS 64496. In BGP, AS 64496
the IP prefix 168.122.0.0/16 as well as its subprefix originates the IP prefix 168.122.0.0/16 as well as its subprefix
168.122.225.0/24. Therefore, the RPKI should contain a ROA 168.122.225.0/24. Therefore, the RPKI should contain a ROA
authorizing AS 111 to originate these two IP prefixes. That is, the authorizing AS 64496 to originate these two IP prefixes. That is,
ROA should be the ROA should be
ROA:(168.122.0.0/16,168.122.225.0/24, AS 111) ROA:(168.122.0.0/16,168.122.225.0/24, AS 64496)
This ROA is "minimal" because it includes only those IP prefixes that This ROA is "minimal" because it includes only those IP prefixes that
AS 111 originates in BGP, but no other IP prefixes. [RFC6907] AS 64496 originates in BGP, but no other IP prefixes [RFC6907].
Now suppose an attacking AS 666 originates a BGP announcement for a Now suppose an attacking AS 64511 originates a BGP announcement for a
subprefix 168.122.0.0/24. This is a standard "subprefix hijack". subprefix 168.122.0.0/24. This is a standard "subprefix hijack".
In the absence of the minimal ROA above, AS 666 could intercept In the absence of the minimal ROA above, AS 64511 could intercept
traffic for the addresses in 168.122.0.0/24. This is because routers traffic for the addresses in 168.122.0.0/24. This is because routers
perform a longest-prefix match when deciding where to forward IP perform a longest-prefix match when deciding where to forward IP
packets, and 168.122.0.0/24 originated by AS 666 is a longer prefix packets, and 168.122.0.0/24 originated by AS 64511 is a longer prefix
than 168.122.0.0/16 originated by AS 111. than 168.122.0.0/16 originated by AS 64496.
However, the minimal ROA renders AS 666's BGP announcement invalid, However, the minimal ROA renders AS 64511's BGP announcement invalid,
because (1) this ROA "covers" the attacker's announcement (since because (1) this ROA "covers" the attacker's announcement (since
168.122.0.0/24 is a subprefix of 168.122.0.0/16), and (2) there is no 168.122.0.0/24 is a subprefix of 168.122.0.0/16), and (2) there is no
ROA "matching" the attacker's announcement (there is no ROA for AS ROA "matching" the attacker's announcement (there is no ROA for AS
666 and IP prefix 168.122.0.0/24) [RFC6811]. If routers ignore 64511 and IP prefix 168.122.0.0/24) [RFC6811]. If routers ignore
invalid BGP announcements, the minimal ROA above ensures that the invalid BGP announcements, the minimal ROA above ensures that the
subprefix hijack will fail. subprefix hijack will fail.
Now suppose that instead the "minimal ROA" was replaced with a "loose Now suppose that the "minimal ROA" was replaced with a "loose ROA"
ROA" that used maxLength as a shorthand for set of IP prefixes that that used maxLength as a shorthand for set of IP prefixes that AS
AS 111 is authorized to originate. The "loose ROA" would be: 64496 is authorized to originate. The "loose ROA" would be:
ROA:(168.122.0.0/16-24, AS 111) ROA:(168.122.0.0/16-24, AS 64496)
This "loose ROA" authorizes AS 111 to originate any subprefix of This "loose ROA" authorizes AS 64496 to originate any subprefix of
168.122.0.0/16, up to length /24. That is, AS 111 could originate 168.122.0.0/16, up to length /24. That is, AS 64496 could originate
168.122.225.0/24 as well as all of 168.122.0.0/17, 168.122.128.0/17, 168.122.225.0/24 as well as all of 168.122.0.0/17, 168.122.128.0/17,
..., 168.122.255.0/24 but not 168.122.0.0/25. ..., 168.122.255.0/24 but not 168.122.0.0/25.
However, AS 111 only originates two prefixes in BGP: 168.122.0.0/16 However, AS 64496 only originates two prefixes in BGP: 168.122.0.0/16
and 168.122.255.0/24. This means that all other prefixes authorized and 168.122.255.0/24. This means that all other prefixes authorized
by the "loose ROA" (for instance, 168.122.0.0/24), are vulnerable to by the "loose ROA" (for instance, 168.122.0.0/24), are vulnerable to
the following forged-origin subprefix hijack [[RFC7115],[GCHSS]]: the following forged-origin subprefix hijack [RFC7115], [GCHSS]:
The hijacker AS 666 sends a BGP announcement "168.122.0.0/24: AS The hijacker AS 64511 sends a BGP announcement "168.122.0.0/24: AS
666, AS 111", falsely claiming that AS 666 is a neighbor of AS 111 64511, AS 64496", falsely claiming that AS 64511 is a neighbor of
and falsely claiming that AS 111 originates the IP prefix AS 64496 and falsely claiming that AS 64496 originates the IP
168.122.0.0/24. In fact, the IP prefix 168.122.0.0/24 is not prefix 168.122.0.0/24. In fact, the IP prefix 168.122.0.0/24 is
originated by AS 111. not originated by AS 64496.
The hijacker's BGP announcement is valid according the RPKI, since The hijacker's BGP announcement is valid according to the RPKI, since
the ROA (168.122.0.0/16-24, AS 111) authorizes AS 111 to originate the ROA (168.122.0.0/16-24, AS 64496) authorizes AS 64496 to
BGP routes for 168.122.0.0/24. Becaue AS 111 does not actually originate BGP routes for 168.122.0.0/24. Because AS 64496 does not
originate a route for 168.122.0.0/24, the hijacker's route is the actually originate a route for 168.122.0.0/24, the hijacker's route
*only* route to the 168.122.0.0/24. Longest-prefix-match routing is the *only* route to the 168.122.0.0/24. Longest-prefix-match
ensures that the hijacker's route to the subprefix 168.122.0.0/24 is routing ensures that the hijacker's route to the subprefix
always preferred over the legitimate route to 168.122.0.0/16 168.122.0.0/24 is always preferred over the legitimate route to
originated by AS 111. Thus, if the hijacker's route propagates 168.122.0.0/16 originated by AS 64496. Thus, the hijacker's route
through the Internet, the hijacker will intercept traffic destined propagates through the Internet, the traffic destined for IP
for IP addresses in 168.122.0.0/24. addresses in 168.122.0.0/24 will be delivered to the hijacker.
The forged origin *subprefix* hijack would have failed if the The forged origin *subprefix* hijack would have failed if the
"minimal ROA" described above was used instead of the "loose ROA". "minimal ROA" described above was used instead of the "loose ROA".
If the "minimal ROA" had been used instead, the attacker would be If the "minimal ROA" had been used instead, the attacker would be
forced to launch a forged origin *prefix* hijack in order to attract forced to launch a forged origin *prefix* hijack in order to attract
traffic, as follows: traffic, as follows:
The hijacker AS 666 sends a BGP announcement "168.122.0.0/16: AS The hijacker AS 64511 sends a BGP announcement "168.122.0.0/16: AS
666, AS 111", falsely claiming that AS 666 is a neighbor of AS 64511, AS 64496", falsely claiming that AS 64511 is a neighbor of
111. AS 64496.
This forged-origin *prefix* hijack is significantly less damaging This forged-origin *prefix* hijack is significantly less damaging
than the forged-origin *subprefix* hijack. With a forged-origin than the forged-origin *subprefix* hijack. With a forged-origin
*prefix* hijack, AS 111 legitimately originates 168.122.0.0/16 in *prefix* hijack, AS 64496 legitimately originates 168.122.0.0/16 in
BGP, so the hijacker AS 666 is not presenting the *only* route to BGP, so the hijacker AS 64511 is not presenting the *only* route to
168.122.0.0/16. Moreover, the path originated by AS 666 is one hop 168.122.0.0/16. Moreover, the path originated by AS 64511 is one hop
longer than the path originated by the legitimate origin AS 111. As longer than the path originated by the legitimate origin AS 64496.
discussed in [LSG16], this means that the hijacker will attract less As discussed in [LSG16], this means that the hijacker will attract
traffic than he would have in the forged origin *subprefix* hijack, less traffic than he would have in the forged origin *subprefix*
where the hijacker presents the *only* route to the hijacked hijack, where the hijacker presents the *only* route to the hijacked
subprefix. subprefix.
In sum, a forged-origin subprefix hijack has the same impact as a In sum, a forged-origin subprefix hijack has the same impact as a
regular subprefix hijack. A forged-origin *subprefix* hijack is also regular subprefix hijack. A forged-origin *subprefix* hijack is also
more damaging than than forged-origin *prefix* hijack. more damaging than forged-origin *prefix* hijack.
Any ROA that is not minimal is vulnerable to forged-origin subprefix
hijack.
4. Measurements of Today's RPKI 4. Measurements of Today's RPKI
Network measurements from June 1, 2017 show that 12% of the IP Network measurements from June 1, 2017 show that 12% of the IP
prefixes authorized in ROAs have a maxLength longer than their prefix prefixes authorized in ROAs have a maxLength longer than their prefix
length. The vast majority of these (84%) of these are vulnerable to length. The vast majority of these (84%) of these are vulnerable to
forged-origin subprefix hijacks. Even large providers are vulnerable forged-origin subprefix hijacks. Even large providers are vulnerable
to these attacks. See [GSG17] for details. to these attacks. See [GSG17] for details.
These measurements suggest that operators commonly misconfigure the These measurements suggest that operators commonly misconfigure the
skipping to change at page 6, line 39 skipping to change at page 6, line 39
In this case, the ROA SHOULD include (1) the set of IP prefixes that In this case, the ROA SHOULD include (1) the set of IP prefixes that
are always originated in BGP, and (2) the set IP prefixes that are are always originated in BGP, and (2) the set IP prefixes that are
sometimes, but not always, originated in BGP. The ROA SHOULD NOT sometimes, but not always, originated in BGP. The ROA SHOULD NOT
include any IP prefixes that the operator knows will not be include any IP prefixes that the operator knows will not be
originated in BGP. Whenever possible, the ROA SHOULD also avoid the originated in BGP. Whenever possible, the ROA SHOULD also avoid the
use of the maxlength attribute. use of the maxlength attribute.

where it is not possible to issue a minimal ROA. where it is not possible to issue a minimal ROA.
Suppose AS 111 has a contract with a DDoS mitigation service provider Consider the following scenario prior to deployment of RPKI. Suppose
that holds AS 222. The DDoS mitigation service is contracted to AS 64496 announced 168.122.0.0/16 and has a contract with a DDoS
protect all IP addresses covered by 168.122.0.0/22. When a DDoS mitigation service provider that holds AS 64500. Further, assume
attack is detected, AS 222 immediately originates 168.122.0.0/22, that the DDoS mitigation service contract applies to all IP addresses
covered by 168.122.0.0/22. When a DDoS attack is detected and
reported by AS111, AS 64500 immediately originates 168.122.0.0/22,
thus attracting all the DDoS traffic to itself. The traffic is thus attracting all the DDoS traffic to itself. The traffic is
scrubbed at AS 222 and then and sent back to AS 111 over a backhaul scrubbed at AS 64500 and then sent back to AS 64496 over a backhaul
data link. Notice that, during a DDoS attack, the DDoS mitigation data link. Notice that, during a DDoS attack, the DDoS mitigation
service provider AS 222 originates a /22 prefix that are longer than service provider AS 64500 originates a /22 prefix that is longer than
than AS 111's /16 prefix, and so all the traffic that normally goes than AS 64496's /16 prefix, and so all the traffic (destined to
to AS 111 goes to AS 222 instead. addresses in 168.122.0.0/22) that normally goes to AS 64496 goes to
AS 64500 instead.
First, suppose the RPKI only had the minimal ROA for AS 111, as First, suppose the RPKI only had the minimal ROA for AS 64496, as
described in Section 3. But, if there is no ROA authorizing AS 222 described in Section 3. But, if there is no ROA authorizing AS 64500
to announce the /23 prefix, then the traffic-scrubbing scheme would to announce the /22 prefix, then the traffic-scrubbing scheme would
not work. That is, if AS 222 originates the /22 prefix in BGP during not work. That is, if AS 64500 originates the /22 prefix in BGP

Instead, the RPKI should have two ROAs: one for AS 111 and one for AS Therefore, the RPKI should have two ROAs: one for AS 64496 and one
222. for AS 64500.
ROA:(168.122.0.0/16,168.122.225.0/24, AS 111) ROA:(168.122.0.0/16,168.122.225.0/24, AS 64496)
ROA:(168.122.0.0/22, AS 222) ROA:(168.122.0.0/22, AS 64500)
Neither ROA uses the maxLength attribute. But, the second ROA is not Neither ROA uses the maxLength attribute. But, the second ROA is not
"minimal" because it contains a /22 prefix that is not originated by "minimal" because it contains a /22 prefix that is not originated by
anyone in BGP during normal operations. The /22 prefix is only anyone in BGP during normal operations. The /22 prefix is only
originated by AS 222 as part of its DDoS mitigation service during a originated by AS 64500 as part of its DDoS mitigation service during
DDoS attack. a DDoS attack.
Notice, however, that this scheme does not come without risks. Notice, however, that this scheme does not come without risks.
Namely, all of the IP addresses in 168.122.0.0/22 are vulnerable to a Namely, all IP addresses in 168.122.0.0/22 are vulnerable to a
forged-origin subprefix hijack during normal operations, when the /22 forged-origin subprefix hijack during normal operations, when the /22
prefix is not originated. (The hijacker AS 666 would send the BGP prefix is not originated. (The hijacker AS 64511 would send the BGP
announcement `168.122.0.0/22: AS 666, AS 222'', falsely claiming that announcement "168.122.0.0/22: AS 64511, AS 64500", falsely claiming
AS 666 is a neighbor of AS 222 and falsely claiming that AS 222 that AS 64511 is a neighbor of AS 64500 and falsely claiming that AS
originates 168.122.0.0/22.) 64500 originates 168.122.0.0/22.)
In some situations, the DDoS mitigation service at AS 222 might want In some situations, the DDoS mitigation service at AS 64500 might
to limit the amount of DDoS traffic that it attracts and scrubs. want to limit the amount of DDoS traffic that it attracts and scrubs.
Suppose that a DDoS attack only targets IP addresses in Suppose that a DDoS attack only targets IP addresses in
168.122.0.0/24. Then, the DDoS mitigation service at AS 222 only 168.122.0.0/24. Then, the DDoS mitigation service at AS 64500 only
wants to attract the traffic destinated for the /24 prefix that is wants to attract the traffic designated for the /24 prefix that is
under attack, but not the entire /22 prefix. To allow for this, the under attack, but not the entire /22 prefix. To allow for this, the
RPKI should have two ROAs: one for AS 111 and one for AS 222. RPKI should have two ROAs: one for AS 64496 and one for AS 64500.
ROA:(168.122.0.0/16,168.122.225.0/24, AS 111) ROA:(168.122.0.0/16,168.122.225.0/24, AS 64496)
ROA:(168.122.0.0/22-24, AS 222) ROA:(168.122.0.0/22-24, AS 64500)

explicitly enable AS 222 to originate *any* /24 subprefix of explicitly enable AS 64500 to originate *any* /24 subprefix of
168.122.0.0/22. 168.122.0.0/22.
As before, the second ROA is also not "minimal" because it contains As before, the second ROA is also not "minimal" because it contains
prefixes that are not originated by anyone in BGP during normal prefixes that are not originated by anyone in BGP during normal
operations. As before, all of the IP addresses in 168.122.0.0/22 are operations. As before, all IP addresses in 168.122.0.0/22 are
vulnerable to a forged-origin subprefix hijack during normal vulnerable to a forged-origin subprefix hijack during normal
operations, when the /22 prefix is not originated. operations, when the /22 prefix is not originated.
The use of maxLength in this second ROA also comes with an additional The use of maxLength in this second ROA also comes with an additional
risk. Consider a DDoS attack that causes the DDoS mitigation service risk. While it permits the DDoS mitigation service at AS 64500 to
at AS 222 to originates prefix 168.122.0.0/24. It follows that all originate prefix 168.122.0.0/24 during a DDoS attack in that space,
*other* /24 prefixes covered by the /22 prefix (i.e., 168.122.1.0/24, it also makes the *other* /24 prefixes covered by the /22 prefix
168.122.2.0/24, 168.122.3.0/24) are all vulnerable to a forged-origin (i.e., 168.122.1.0/24, 168.122.2.0/24, 168.122.3.0/24) vulnerable to
subprefix attacks during the DDoS attack. a forged-origin subprefix attacks.
6. Change Log
Note to RFC Editor: if this document does not obsolete an existing
RFC, please remove this appendix before publication as an RFC.
00 - New document.
01 - Updated network measurements. Updated citation to [GSG17].
Editorial changes to clarify difference between "minimal ROA"
recommendation and "avoid maxLength" recommendation. Updated
example in Section 5.1.
